revision.text:
{{pp-move|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Olivia Munn |image = Olivia Munn by Gage Skidmore.jpg |caption = Munn at the 2018 [[San Diego Comic-Con]]. |birth_name = Lisa Olivia Munn |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|7|3}} |birth_place = [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], U.S. |occupation = {{hlist| Actress| model }} |yearsactive = 2004–present |alma_mater = [[University of Oklahoma]] }}
'''Lisa Olivia Munn''' (born July 3, 1980) is an American actress and model. She began her professional career in television journalism before becoming an actress. In 2006, Munn starred as Mily Acuna on the series ''[[Beyond the Break]]''. She co-hosted ''[[Attack of the Show!]]'' from 2006 to 2010 and was a correspondent on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' from 2010 to 2011.
Munn has also had supporting roles in various films and television series since 2004. She played the character Sloan Sabbith on the television series ''[[The Newsroom (U.S. TV series)|The Newsroom]]'' from 2012 to 2014, and has appeared in the films ''[[Magic Mike]]'' (2012), the horror film ''[[Deliver Us from Evil (2014 film)|Deliver Us from Evil]]'' (2014), the comedy ''[[Mortdecai (film)|Mortdecai]]'' (2014), and ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' (2016) as [[Psylocke]]. In 2017, she provided the voice of Koko in ''[[The Lego Ninjago Movie]]'', and also had a lead role on the [[History (U.S. TV network)|History Channel]] series ''[[Six (TV series)|Six]]'' (2017).
==Early life== Lisa Olivia Munn was born July 3, 1980<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Famous-birthdays-for-July-3-Tom-Cruise-Olivia-Munn/6681498850891/|title=Famous birthdays for July 3: Tom Cruise, Olivia Munn|date=July 3, 2017 |agency=[[United Press International]] |accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref> in [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]]. Her father, Winston Barrett Munn, is an American of English, Irish and German descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eng.alostouramagazine.com/2015/05/02/style-battle-olivia-wilde-vs-olivia-munn/|title=Style Battle – Olivia Wilde Vs Olivia Munn |date=2 May 2015}}</ref> Her mother, Kimberly Schmid, was born and raised in Vietnam, and is of Chinese descent.<ref name=shattuck>{{cite web|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/movies/olivia-munn-has-a-fallback-plan-neurosurgery.html|accessdate=June 16, 2018|date=November 25, 2016|title=Olivia Munn Has a Fallback Plan: Neurosurgery|last=Shattuck |first=Kathryn}} {{closed access}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2016/01/08/aaron-rodgers-impresses-olivia-munns-mom-vietnamese-blogs/|title=Aaron Rodgers impresses Olivia Munn's mom, Vietnamese blogs|website=New York Post|first=Jaclyn|last=Hendricks|date= January 8, 2016|accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> Her mother was a Vietnamese refugee who fled to Oklahoma in 1975 after the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name="Moviefone">{{cite web| title= Olivia Munn Facts: 29 Things You (Probably) Don't Know About the Actress| website= [[Moviefone]]|url=http://www.moviefone.com/2014/07/04/olivia-munn-facts/|date=July 4, 2014}}</ref> After college, her mother married Winston.<ref name= oceandrive>{{cite news |url=http://oceandrive.com/personalities/articles/olivia-munn-hollywoods-hottest-geek|title=Olivia Munn: Hollywood's Hottest Geek| newspaper= Ocean Drive|last= Pacheco| first= Patrick|date=May–June 2012|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.zimbio.com/Olivia+Munn/articles/60/Tokyo+Dance+Trooper+G4TV+Olivia+Munn |title=Tokyo Dance Trooper with G4TV's Olivia Munn| website= ZimBio.com| accessdate= May 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| first= Christopher John |last= Farley |date=June 5, 2010| url= https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/06/05/daily-show-correspondent-olivia-munn-on-joining-the-show/ |title= 'Daily Show' Correspondent Olivia Munn on Joining the Program| |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| accessdate= June 5, 2012}} {{closed access}}</ref>
When Munn was two years old, her parents divorced and her mother remarried to a member of the [[United States Air Force]]. Although the family relocated many times, Munn was predominantly raised on [[Yokota Air Base]] near [[Tachikawa]] in [[Tokyo]], Japan,<ref name=about>{{cite web|url=http://www.oliviamunn.com/about/|title=About|first= Olivia |last= Munn |authorlink=Olivia Munn| website=OliviaMunn.com| publisher=COMPLEXMediaNetwork| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5onUdX7G5?url=http://www.oliviamunn.com/about/| archivedate= April 6, 2010 | accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="G4">{{cite interview| subject= Munn, Olivia|interviewer=sjohnson|title=Just Who is Olivia Munn?|website=G4TV|date= April 7, 2006 |url= http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/blog/post/577916/Just_Who_is_Olivia_Munn.html| accessdate=October 28, 2007}}</ref> where her stepfather was stationed. During this time, she appeared in a number of local theater productions and later became a model in the Japanese fashion industry.<ref name="Ask">{{cite web| title= Olivia Munn| website= AskMen.com|url=http://www.askmen.com/women/models_300/395c_olivia_munn.html|accessdate=October 28, 2007}}</ref> She has said that her stepfather was "verbally abusive" and demeaning.<ref>{{Citation |url= https://oceandrive.com/olivia-munn-hollywoods-hottest-geek |magazine=Ocean Drive |title= Olivia Munn: Hollywood's Hottest Geek |first= Patrick |last= Pacheco |date=May 1, 2012 }}</ref> Munn has one brother, John, a physicist, and a sister, Sara, who is a lawyer.<ref>{{cite interview |work=The Tonight Show|interviewer=[[Jimmy Fallon]]|date=October 31, 2014|last=Munn|first=Olivia|publisher=NBC|accessdate=June 15, 2018|title=Olivia Munn Is the Family Disappointment}} {{Youtube|zUNYoy6x5Rk}}.</ref>
Her mother and stepfather divorced when Munn was a teenager, and she moved back to Oklahoma with her mother, where she attended [[Putnam City North High School]] for her junior and senior years of high school.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsok.com/article/3533333 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205081338/http://newsok.com/article/3533333 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 5, 2011 |date=January 21, 2011 |title=OU graduate Olivia Munn gets 'Perfect' in new show |website=NewsOK |accessdate=January 21, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.putnamcityschools.org/District/DistrictHistory/BooksbyPutnamCityGraduates.aspx| title= Books by Putnam City Graduates|publisher=Putnam City Schools|accessdate= April 1, 2016}}</ref> After graduating, Munn attended the [[University of Oklahoma]], where she earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[journalism]] with a minor in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and dramatic arts.<ref name=shattuck/><ref>{{cite web |website=The Wrap|url=https://www.thewrap.com/newsroom-olivia-munn-puts-her-journalism-degree-use-video-102891/|accessdate=June 16, 2018|title=With 'The Newsroom,' Olivia Munn Puts Her Journalism Degree to Use|date=July 24, 2014|last1=Keavy |first1= Madisen |last2=Papenhausen |first2=Sydney }}</ref>
==Career== ===2004–2009: Beginnings=== [[File:Olivia Munn.JPG|thumb|upright|Munn signing autographs for ''Attack of the Show!'' at the 2007 Comic Con]] After graduating, she became an intern at [[KJRH-TV|the NBC affiliate]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]],<ref>[//www.youtube.com/watch?v=bsBF1ZPRWMY "Olivia Munn & Sam Roberts on News Room, Magic Mike, Nude Scene, Leaving G4, & more"]. [[YouTube]]. June 27 2013. Retrieved August 25, 2013.</ref> and later moved to [[Los Angeles]] to pursue an acting career. In 2004, Munn interned at [[Fox Sports Networks]] and worked as a [[sideline reporter]] for college football and women's basketball. She has gone on to say that she disliked the experience, explaining, "I was trying to be something I wasn't, and that made me really uncomfortable on live TV."<ref name="G4"/> Soon after she moved to Los Angeles, Munn was cast in a small role in the [[direct-to-video]] [[horror film]] ''[[Scarecrow Gone Wild]]''. She appeared in rock band [[Zebrahead]]'s music video for their song "Hello Tomorrow" as the love interest of the lead singer [[Justin Mauriello]].<ref>{{youtube|Epe2dfFwSVo|Olivia Munn in Zebrahead Music Video}} Retrieved 6 December 2008.</ref> Munn also appeared in ''National Lampoon's Strip Poker'', which was filmed at [[Hedonism Resorts|Hedonism II]], a [[naturism|naturist]] resort in [[Negril]], [[Jamaica]], with [[Kato Kaelin]]. The films aired on [[DirecTV]] and [[In Demand]] [[pay-per-view]].
In late 2005, Munn began her role as teen surfer Mily Acuna over two seasons of the television drama ''Beyond the Break'' on [[TeenNick|The N network]].<ref name="g4tv">{{cite web|first=Stephen A. |last=Johnson|date=April 15, 2006|url=http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/features/53663/AOTS_hosts_Kevin_Pereira_and_Olivia_Munn.html|title=AOTS hosts Kevin Pereira and Olivia Munn|publisher=G4TV|accessdate=October 31, 2007}}</ref> She enjoys surfing and continues to practice the sport.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bean |first=Matt |title=Adventure as Aphrodisiac |website=menshealth.com|url= http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=sex.relationships&category=couples&conitem=70f3dce9c5443110VgnVCM20000012281eac____&page=1| accessdate=October 29, 2007}}</ref> She originally auditioned for the role of Kai Kealoha, but the producers wanted a "local girl".<ref name="blog013107"/> She also appeared in the film ''The Road to Canyon Lake''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.beautyworldnews.com/articles/9245/20140514/newsroom-actress-olivia-munn-dating-green-bay-packers-quarterback-aaron-rodgers.htm|title='The Newsroom' actress Olivia Munn dating Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers|first=Amber|last=Belus|publisher=Beauty World News|date=May 14, 2014|accessdate=April 1, 2016}}</ref>
In 2006, Munn moved on to the [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4 network]], where she began co-hosting ''Attack of the Show!'' with [[Kevin Pereira]] on 10th April. She replaced departing host Sarah Lane. The network, devoted to the world of video games and the video games lifestyle, was at first hesitant to hire Munn. Although she admits video games were her "weak point", she was confident in her technical knowledge.<ref>"Playboy after hours – babe of the month" (February 2007) ''[[Playboy]]'', as seen in: {{cite news|title=Olivia Munn in Playboy!|publisher=[[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]]|date=January 18, 2007|url=http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/blog/post/672882/Olivia_Munn_in_Playboy.html|accessdate=October 28, 2007}}.</ref> On the show, Munn was featured with journalist [[Anna David (journalist)|Anna David]] in a segment called "In Your Pants", which deals with sex and relationship questions from viewers. While working on ''Attack of the Show!'', Munn hosted ''[[Formula D]]'', a now defunct program about American [[drifting (motorsport)|drift racing]], and an online [[podcast]] called ''Around the Net'', formerly known as ''The Daily Nut'', for G4. Munn left ''Attack of the Show!'' in December 2010 and was replaced by [[Candace Bailey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/olivia-munn-aots-1027663/ |title=Olivia Munn: Why I Left 'Attack Of The Show' |first=Kate|last=Stanhopet|date=January 13, 2011|access-date= April 1, 2016}}</ref> Munn appeared in the [[Rob Schneider]] film ''[[Big Stan]]'' (2007). She played Schneider's character's receptionist Maria.<ref name="G4"/> Munn had a significant role in the horror film ''[[Insanitarium]]'' in which she played a nurse at an insane asylum.
===2010–present: Breakthrough=== [[File:Olivia Munn 2013.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Munn at the 2013 ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' Women of the Year Awards]] She had roles in the films ''[[Date Night]]'' (2010) and ''[[Iron Man 2]]'' (2010). [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] praised Munn for her improvisation skills and led the crew in a round of applause.<ref>{{cite web|date=December 14, 2009|first=Blair |last=Marnell|title=Olivia Munn Talks 'Iron Man 2' Improv| url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2009/12/14/olivia-munn-talks-iron-man-2-improv/ |work=MTV Splash Page|publisher=Viacom| accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> Munn hosted [[Microsoft]]'s Bing-a-thon, an advertisement on [[Hulu]] for the Microsoft search-engine [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]], on 8 June 2009, alongside [[Jason Sudeikis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2009/06/02/bingathon/|title=Bing-a-thon on mashable.com}}</ref> Munn appeared in [[ABC Family]]'s ''[[Greek (TV series)|Greek]]'', portraying Cappie's love interest, Lana. In May 2010, [[NBC]] announced that Munn would star on the television series ''[[Perfect Couples]]''. The half-hour romantic comedy premiered on January 20, 2011.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.nbc.com/news/2010/05/12/nbc-announces-pickup-of-new-comedy-series-perfect-couples-for-2010-11-season/ |title=NBC Announces Pickup of New Comedy Series 'Perfect Couples' For 2010–11 Season |date=May 12, 2010 |publisher=[[NBC Universal]] |accessdate=May 12, 2010 |archivedate=May 14, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514084406/http://www.nbc.com/news/2010/05/12/nbc-announces-pickup-of-new-comedy-series-perfect-couples-for-2010-11-season/ |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The series was cancelled before it completed its first season run.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zap |first=Claudine|date=April 8, 2011|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/blog/byebye-perfect-couples-hello-paul-reiser-show--2722|title=Bye-Bye, 'Perfect Couples,' Hello 'Paul Reiser Show'|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110417194925/https://tv.yahoo.com/blog/byebye-perfect-couples-hello-paul-reiser-show--2722 |archive-date=April 17, 2011 |work=[[Yahoo! TV]]|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref>
On June 3, 2010, Munn debuted in her new role as a correspondent on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''The Daily Show''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/06/olivia-munn-daily-show-coorespondant-.html |title=Olivia Munn 'trying out' as 'Daily Show' correspondent |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=June 3, 2010 |accessdate=June 4, 2010 |archivedate=June 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607172818/http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/06/olivia-munn-daily-show-coorespondant-.html |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Her hiring prompted criticism from [[Irin Carmon]] of ''[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]'', who questioned Munn's credentials and said the show's production was [[sexism|sexist]] for hiring Munn, whom Carmon said was a [[sex symbol]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Carmon |first=Irin|url=http://jezebel.com/5558063/olivia-munns-geek-goddess-schtick|title=Olivia Munn's Geek Goddess Schtick|website=[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]|date= June 8, 2010|accessdate= July 9, 2010}}</ref> Carmon said Munn's hiring was a perpetuation of the show production office's history as a male-dominated atmosphere marginalizing and alienating to women.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carmon |first= Irin |date=June 23, 2010|url=https://archive.is/20120712200020/http://jezebel.com/5570545/|title=The Daily Show's Woman Problem|website=Jezebel|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> A group of thirty-two female ''Daily Show'' production staff members said Carmon's piece as inaccurate and misinformed. Munn said that Carmon's assertion was an insult both to her and to the rest of the ''Daily Show'' staff.<ref>Abrams-Maidenberg, Teri et al. (June 2010) {{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/message |title=Women of The Daily Show Speak |publisher=''The Daily Show'' |accessdate=December 25, 2011 |archivedate=January 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116134415/http://www.thedailyshow.com/message |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>Hepola, Sarah (July 7, 2010). [http://www.salon.com/books/int/2010/07/07/olivia_munn_interview/index.html "Olivia Munn: 'I'm easy to hate. I get it'"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709101426/http://www.salon.com/books/int/2010/07/07/olivia_munn_interview/index.html |date=July 9, 2010 }}. [[Salon.com]]. Retrieved July 12, 2010.</ref> She went on to appear in 16 more episodes as a correspondent, with ''[[TV Guide]]'' naming her signature segment "Tiger Mothering," in which she mocked the high expectations of Chinese mothers, in part by interviewing her own mother.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rudolph |first=Ileane|date=July 27, 2015|title=Alumni Association: A roundup of ''The Daily Show''{{'}}s coolest Graduates|magazine=[[TV Guide]]|pages=21-22|issn=0039-8543}}</ref> Her last episode as a correspondent aired September 2, 2011. She returned for a brief segment in host [[Jon Stewart]]'s final show on August 6, 2015.
In 2010, Munn guest-starred on NBC's comedy-drama ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' as a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] agent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/olivia-munn-chuck-1020777/|title=Her Quest for World Domination Continues: Olivia Munn to Guest-Star on Chuck|newspaper=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate= July 21, 2010}}</ref> In 2011, Munn appeared in the comedy film ''[[I Don't Know How She Does It]]'' (2011) as Momo. In 2012, Munn had a leading role in ''[[The Babymakers]]'', a minor role in ''[[Freeloaders (film)|Freeloaders]]'', and appeared in ''Magic Mike'', directed by [[Steven Soderbergh]]. She played Sloan Sabbith on [[HBO]]'s drama series ''The Newsroom''. She also appeared as Angie, Nick's stripper girlfriend, in three episodes in Season Two of FOX's sitcom ''[[New Girl]]''.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Cabin|series=New Girl|date=January 8, 2013|network=FOX}}</ref>
Munn served as a correspondent in "True Colors," the May 12, 2014 episode of the Showtime documentary series ''[[Years of Living Dangerously]]'', in which she interviewed Washington State Governor [[Jay Inslee]] about his efforts to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in his home state. As of June 2014, Munn has been hired as the main promoter of Proactiv acne cleanser products starring in several commercials and one infomercial for the product. The commercials show Munn experiencing acne herself. Since January 2015, she has been the voice of the character Phoebe Callisto on the [[Disney Junior]] animated series ''[[Miles from Tomorrowland]]''. In 2016, Munn was cast as [[Psylocke|Elizabeth Braddock / Psylocke]] (one of [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]'s Four Horsemen) in ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' and will reprise the role in 2019's ''[[X-Men: Dark Phoenix]]''.
Beginning in 2017, she has a starring role in the television series ''[[Six (TV series)|Six]]'' as a [[CIA]] operative.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Culture/olivia-munn-opens-returning-tv-cias-best-operative/story?id=55479012|network=ABC News|title= Olivia Munn opens up about returning to TV as 'the CIA's best operative'|accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref>
==In print== [[File:Olivia Munn & Joel McHale (13950135434).jpg|thumb|Munn with ''Deliver Us from Evil'' co-star [[Joel McHale]] at the 2014 WonderCon]] Munn has appeared in advertising campaigns for [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Pepsi]] and [[Neutrogena]]. She appeared on the Fall 2006 cover of ''Foam'' magazine in September, in ''Men's Edge'' magazine in August, and was featured in a pictorial in ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' in November 2006, where she later became a columnist.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.complex.com/CELEBRITIES/Profiles/Olivia-Munn|title=Complex's New Columnist: Olivia Munn|publisher=Complex|accessdate=December 6, 2008}}</ref> In February 2007, she appeared as "Babe of the Month" in a non-nude pictorial in ''[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]]'' magazine.<ref name="blog013107">{{cite web|last=Munn |first= Olivia |authorlink=Olivia Munn |title=Hello TV Land!! |magazine=[[TV Guide]]| date=January 31, 2007 |url=http://community.tvguide.com/blog/Celebrity-Blogs/Olivia-Attacks-Blog/700011216 |accessdate=October 31, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027162317/http://community.tvguide.com/blog/Celebrity-Blogs/Olivia-Attacks-Blog/700011216 |archivedate=October 27, 2007 }}</ref> She discusses this shoot in her book ''Suck it, Wonder Woman''.<ref>Hess, Amanda (June 30, 2010). [http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/sexist/2010/06/30/consent-and-manipulation-in-olivia-munns-playboy-shoot/ "Consent and Manipulation in Olivia Munn's Playboy Shoot"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423164153/http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/sexist/2010/06/30/consent-and-manipulation-in-olivia-munns-playboy-shoot/ |date=April 23, 2016 }}. ''[[Washington City Paper]]''. Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref>
Munn also appeared in the July/August 2007 issue of ''[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]''. In September 2007, she was featured in the Italian ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' for their "Hot Young Hollywood" Issue. Munn appeared in the Winter/Spring 2009 issue of ''Men's Health Living''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.menshealthliving.com/learn/My-Bedroom-Olivia-Munn.php |last=Vontz |first=Andrew |title=Olivia Munn in Men's Health Living |publisher=Men's Health Living |accessdate= December 6, 2008 |archivedate=December 7, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207095212/http://www.menshealthliving.com/learn/My-Bedroom-Olivia-Munn.php |deadurl=yes }}</ref> She was featured as the cover girl for the July/August 2009 issue of ''Playboy'', and later on the cover of the January 2010 and February 2011 issues of ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''. Munn appears on the cover of the January 2012 issue of ''[[FHM]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trendrabbit.com/2011/12/olivia-munn-poses-topless-for-hot-fhm-magazine-photoshoot/|title=Olivia Munn FHM Cover, January 2012|website=Trendrabbit.com}}</ref> She was voted #2 by readers on ''Maxim''{{'}}s list of their Hot 100 Women of 2012.<ref name="Maxim-2">{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/hot-100/2012|title=2012 Hot 100: The Definitive List of the World's Most Beautiful Women|publisher=''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''|accessdate=August 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Maxim2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/slideshow/hot-100/43451?slide=98# |title=2012 Hot 100 |publisher=''Maxim'' |accessdate=August 21, 2012 |archivedate=23 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823010244/http://www.maxim.com/slideshow/hot-100/43451?slide=98%23 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Munn's book ''Suck It, Wonder Woman: The Misadventures of a Hollywood Geek'' ({{ISBN|0-312-59105-5}}) was released on July 6, 2010. In a review for ''[[Time Out New York]]'', Olivia Giovetti said that the book offers glimpses into Munn's life, but does not go into depth.<ref>{{cite news|last==Giovetti |first= Olivia |url=http://newyork.timeout.com/arts-culture/books/74617/suck-it-wonder-woman|title=Suck It, Wonder Woman!: Munn fans rejoice, all others proceed with caution |magazine=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out New York]]|date=28 June 2010|accessdate= August 3, 2010}}</ref>
==Charity work== In 2011, Munn teamed up with Dosomething.org's Green Your School Challenge. She was a spokesperson for the campaign by filming a PSA regarding the challenge, and sat on the panel of judges that evaluated the entries.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cernansky |first= Rachel |title=Green Your School: Take The DoSomething.Org Challenge|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2011/02/green-your-school-take-the-dosomething-challenge.php?campaign=th_rss_takeaction |website=Treehugger.com|date= February 3, 2011|accessdate=August 3, 2011}}</ref>
Munn helped [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] with a campaign that ultimately freed a sick elephant from a touring circus. Her blog for ''[[The Huffington Post]]''<ref>Munn, Olivia (November 21, 2011). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/olivia-munn/ringling-bros-animal-abuse-elephants_b_1106802.html "Sarah Cannot Wait Another Day"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303210236/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/olivia-munn/ringling-bros-animal-abuse-elephants_b_1106802.html |date=3 March 2016 }}. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref> was credited with encouraging fans to contact the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] on the elephant's behalf.<ref>Daily Dish (November 29, 2011). [http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2011/11/29/olivia-munn-celebrates-after-ailing-elephant-is-saved/ "Olivia Munn Celebrates After Ailing Elephant Is Saved"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304225300/http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2011/11/29/olivia-munn-celebrates-after-ailing-elephant-is-saved/ |date= March 4, 2016 }}. ''San Francisco Chronicle'' Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref> Munn posed for PETA's "I'd Rather Go Naked Than Wear Fur" campaign in April 2010,<ref>FITSNews (April 28, 2010). [http://www.fitsnews.com/2010/04/28/olivia-munn-wants-elephants-to-run-free/ "Olivia Munn Wants Elephants To Run Free"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185334/http://www.fitsnews.com/2010/04/28/olivia-munn-wants-elephants-to-run-free/ |date=March 4, 2016 }}. fitsnews.com. Retrieved January 13, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.peta.org/features/olivia-munn/ "Olivia Munn Combats Circus Cruelty"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127204433/http://www.peta.org/features/olivia-munn/ |date=November 27, 2016 }}. [[PETA]]. Retrieved January 13, 2011.</ref> and again in January 2012.{{better source|date=June 2018}}<ref>{{cite news|last=Everett |first=Cristina|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/olivia-munn-poses-nude-peta-latest-naked-wear-fur-ad-campaign-article-1.1005682|title=Olivia Munn naked billboard for PETA's anti-fur campaign|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|date=January 13, 2012|accessdate=January 13, 2012}}</ref> In February 2013, Munn fronted a PETA release of new footage showing cruelty to animals in Chinese fur farms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/381117/Animals-electrocuted-strangled-and-skinned-alive-The-true-face-of-China-s-fur-farms|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|title=Animals electrocuted, strangled and skinned alive: The true face of China's fur farms|last=Meredith |first= Charlotte |date=March 1, 2013|accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Munn was in a relationship with [[Green Bay Packers]] quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] from 2014 to 2017.<ref name="peoplemag">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/celebrity/olivia-munn-aaron-rodgers-split/?xid=socialflow_twitter_peoplemag|title=Olivia Munn and Aaron Rodgers Break Up|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=April 7, 2017|accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref>
In regard to her faith and work in ''[[Deliver Us from Evil (2014 film)|Deliver Us from Evil]]'', Munn has said that "I didn't believe in the supernatural before this movie." However, the viewing of footage from the [[New York City Police Department]] of real-life [[Exorcism in Christianity|exorcisms]] changed her mind, and she has stated that "I'm a full believer [now]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/news/deliver-us-from-evil-made-olivia-munn-into-supernatural-believer|title=Deliver Us From Evil made Olivia Munn into supernatural believer|last=Hasty|first=Katie|date=April 25, 2014|work=[[HitFix]]|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://videos.huffingtonpost.com/entertainment/olivia-munn-says-shes-a-believer-after-working-on-deliver-us-from-evil-518205740|title=Olivia Munn Says She's a Believer After Working on 'Deliver Us from Evil'|website=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref>
Munn is a [[black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] in [[taekwondo]].<ref>{{cite web|magazine=Elle|title=5 Things Olivia Munn Did to Get Her Body X-Men Ready |last=Rodulfo |first= Kristina|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=June 14, 2018|url=http://www.elle.com/beauty/health-fitness/news/a36006/olivia-munn-x-men-training-workout/}}</ref>
In November 2017, Munn accused film director [[Brett Ratner]] of repeatedly [[sexual harassment|sexually harassing]] her over a period of several years.<ref>{{Cite news|first1=Amy|last1=Kaufman|first2=Daniel|last2=Miller|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-brett-ratner-allegations-20171101-htmlstory.html|title=Six women accuse filmmaker Brett Ratner of sexual harassment or misconduct|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=November 1, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
